speaker: Roz
text: Hey, Daphne.

speaker: Daphne
text: Hello, Roz, Alice.  What brings you here?

speaker: Roz
text: We're borrowing Frasier's car.

speaker: Daphne
text: Oh, I see.  And you're leaving Alice here as collateral.

speaker: Roz
text: Actually, he's being very nice about it.  Mine's in the shop, and I'm taking Alice and a few of her friends to an ice cream party.

speaker: Frasier
text: [_emerging from hallway_] You told me it was _your_ friends, and the Science Center!

speaker: Roz
text: He said, she said, we'll never know what really happened. Frasier, don't be so uptight.  I'm not gonna hurt your precious car.

speaker: Frasier
text: I am not uptight, it's just that I've had some unfortunate experiences before loaning out my car.

speaker: Daphne
text: [_going to the hall_] I left an umbrella in the trunk.

speaker: Frasier
text: It was a wet umbrella!

speaker: Roz
text: Can I have the keys?

speaker: Frasier
text: [_sighs_] Yes, yes. [_drops them in her hand_] After all, what are fine possessions for if not to be used and enjoyed? [_lugubrious_] And who better to enjoy them than the delightful souls of small children?

speaker: Roz
text: I'll put a tarp in the backseat.

speaker: Frasier
text: Oh, bless you.

speaker: Niles
text: Hey Roz, hello Alice.  What brings you here?

speaker: Roz
text: Oh, Frasier loaned me his car, I backed mine into a telephone pole.

speaker: Frasier
text: You said you were getting a tune-up!

speaker: Roz
text: [_as the elevator doors close_] It needs one, trust me!

speaker: Niles
text: Is, uh, Daphne ready?

speaker: Frasier
text: Uh, actually I think she's in her room.  You two have plans?

speaker: Niles
text: Yes, I am taking her to the botanical gardens.  Can you believe she's never been before?

speaker: Frasier
text: Didn't Donny take her to the botanical gardens last year?

speaker: Niles
text: Can you believe she's never been before?

speaker: Niles
text: Hey, Daphne!

speaker: Daphne
text: Hello, Niles.

speaker: Niles
text: Ready to go to the gardens?

speaker: Daphne
text: Yeah, I'm afraid I'm gonna have to take Eddie for a walk first. [_kisses him_]

speaker: Niles
text: Where's Dad?

speaker: Daphne
text: I don't know, he's been gone all morning.

speaker: Niles
text: Oh well, here, I'll take him for a quick walk.

speaker: Daphne
text: Oh no, he's gonna need more than that, or he'll go stir-crazy. He's gonna need a full hour at the dog park.

speaker: Niles
text: [_checks his watch_] We don't have time to go the dog park, the-the Tour of Succulents starts promptly at twelve.  Uh, hey, Frasier, can you take him?

speaker: Frasier
text: No, I'm sorry, Niles.  Roz has my car, you see, and Lana's coming by to pick me up for a tutoring session with Kirby.

speaker: Daphne
text: I'll just get Eddie's toys. [_leaves_]

speaker: Frasier
text: [_on phone_] Hello, this is Dr. Frasier Crane, I need to make an emergency appointment tomorrow, for a complete cleaning of my BMW.  June 10th?!  But I've got a Clean Team Privileges Card!  Yes, of course it's a platinum one! [_takes it out and looks_] No, no there are no diamonds on the corner.  Well, then yes, I'd like to become a member of the Diamond Alliance immediately.  Fine, put me on the waiting list.  I'll see you in June. [_hangs up_]

speaker: Niles
text: [_needling_] You're not in the Diamond Alliance?

speaker: Frasier
text: Don't do that! _FADE OUT  Scene Two - Park Niles and Daphne are sitting together on a bench in the park, with Eddie.  All around them are dogs playing with their owners._

speaker: Niles
text: So this is it.

speaker: Daphne
text: Mmm-hmm.

speaker: Niles
text: I'd hardly call this a dog park. [_looks around_] It's more like a dog... orgy.  Whose beagles are those?

speaker: Daphne
text: Don't stare, it only encourages them.

speaker: Niles
text: Well, hurry up, Eddie, there's lots of exciting depravity to explore. [_Eddie doesn't move_]

speaker: Daphne
text: [_takes out a short piece of thick rope_] He wants to play a little fetch.

speaker: Niles
text: Oh.

speaker: Daphne
text: Well here, you throw it.

speaker: Niles
text: With my bare hands?

speaker: Daphne
text: Oh come on, it's fun.

speaker: Niles
text: [_takes it_] Ready?  Here we go.  And, fetch! _He tosses the rope about two feet away.  Eddie quickly picks it up and brings it back._

speaker: Niles
text: All right, I didn't give you enough of a challenge.  Here, ready, ready?  And, ho! [_throws it farther_] Go get it! [_Eddie runs after it_] I'm sorry, I was a bit of a grouch. This is actually a fine way to spend the day.

speaker: Daphne
text: Yeah...

speaker: Niles
text: In fact, it's kind of... _He trails off as a huge hound comes back with the end of the rope hanging from his jaws._

speaker: Niles
text: Hello.  Do you suppose the rest of Eddie's in there? _Jim, a tall, handsome, athletic man, follows the hound. Eddie follows him._

speaker: Jim
text: Good boy, good boy!  Sorry about that, Daphne, but what with the organic vitamin paste I've been feeding Tank here, Eddie can't keep up with him.

speaker: Daphne
text: It's no problem, Jim.  Uh, Niles, this is Jim Grady and Tank. This is Niles, my boyfriend.

speaker: Niles
text: [_shaking hands_] Pleasure.

speaker: Jim
text: Boyfriend?  Ah, I should have known.  It seems like every time I'm single you're in a relationship, and every time you're single I'm in a relationship.

speaker: Daphne
text: Yeah, that's true.

speaker: Jim
text: I guess we just don't have-

speaker: Daphne
text: Timing!

speaker: Jim
text: -good... [_Daphne laughs_] And I'm a drummer!

speaker: Niles
text: Which, uh, makes it even more ironic!

speaker: Jim
text: Tank, that's rude!  Now, chill. [_Tank obeys_]

speaker: Niles
text: Wow.

speaker: Daphne
text: Wow, you've really got him trained.  That's the problem with Eddie.  He only listens when he thinks he's gonna get food.

speaker: Niles
text: Or one of my socks! [_laughs, no one else does_] But mostly food.

speaker: Jim
text: Well, it's all in the voice tone, really.  Any dog can learn to respond to it, even an old wheezer like Eddie.  You, uh, want me to show you?

speaker: Daphne
text: I'd love it.

speaker: Jim
text: Come on. [_she gets up_]

speaker: Niles
text: Yeah, we'd all love it!

speaker: Niles
text: Oh uh, you guys, uh... [_but they're gone_] Be right back. [_sits and answers_] Hello?! _SMASH CUT TO:  A close-up of Martin, dressed in a dark suit and talking on a mobile:_

speaker: Martin
text: Hi Niles, it's me.  I just wanted to make sure Daphne took Eddie for a walk, I completely forgot about it this morning.

speaker: Niles
text: Yeah, yeah, we're in the dog park now.  Uh, where are you, anyway? _The camera widens to show Martin seated at a table in a nondescript room.  It looks a little like a canteen.  In the background are two people in suits, conferring._

speaker: Martin
text: Uh, I'm at the track.  Uh, had an itch for it when I woke up, and so just I dropped everything and went.  Uh, I'm at the window... [_puts the phone to his shoulder_] I'll have a trifecta in the eighth. [_into phone_] All right, gotta run.

speaker: Niles
text: Wait, uh- _Martin hangs up.  He looks very pensive.  FADE TO:_ **MR. HAPPY PANTS** _Scene Three - House Lana opens the door to the house, and Frasier follows her in._

speaker: Frasier
text: Well, I didn't realize that I was going to be selling houses with you today!  Why didn't you just drop me off and then come on your own?

speaker: Lana
text: Stop whining!  It'll only take a minute.  I hope we don't run into the sad sack who owns this place. _She notices some framed family pictures on the otherwise bare shelves, and quickly removes them to a box on the floor._

speaker: Lana
text: I've been trying to sell this house for over a year!  But he keeps driving away every potential buyer.

speaker: Frasier
text: How does he do that? _Phillip, the world's saddest man (judging by his unshaven face and filthy clothes) lumbers in carrying a box._

speaker: Phillip
text: Oh... hi.  I heard a woman's voice, I thought it might be my wife coming back to me.

speaker: Lana
text: [_as if to a child_] No.  She lives in Portland now, with her new husband, Lamar, remember? [_Phillip nods sadly_] Oh, excuse me, Frasier Crane, Phillip Donovan, the current owner.

speaker: Frasier
text: Hello.

speaker: Phillip
text: Hi.

speaker: Lana
text: Well, see you later Phillip! _Not seeming to hear her, Phillip puts the box on the floor and sinks onto the couch._

speaker: Phillip
text: Anyway, my wife just left with the kids.  No talking, no explanations, just ripped my heart out and threw it to the dogs - which she also took.

speaker: Frasier
text: Well, uh, at least you're... getting out at the top of the market!

speaker: Lana
text: Actually, this is a very good time, Phillip, and I think today is the day!

speaker: Phillip
text: [_opening the box_] Oh, no!

speaker: Lana
text: Oh, God!

speaker: Frasier
text: What's wrong?

speaker: Phillip
text: The damn basement must have flooded again.  Everything in this box is ruined.  Little Suzy's cap she wore home from the hospital, ruined; Danny's first soccer uniform, ruined!

speaker: Frasier
text: Well, you know, I have an excellent drycleaner-

speaker: Lana
text: [_hissed_] No! _Frasier drops his coat onto a chair and sits beside Phillip on the couch._

speaker: Frasier
text: Once, actually, I spilled butter on a pair of white velvet pantaloons. [_off their looks_] Well, it's a long story. But, uh, he had it out in under a minute!

speaker: Lana
text: Frasier, just give him the address.

speaker: Frasier
text: Yes, yes...

speaker: Phillip
text: [_shows him some pictures_] I have two sons and two daughters. The perfect American family... until that bastard Lamar showed up to snake our drains.  Now all I have left are weekend visits, and a few treasures from their childhood.

speaker: Phillip
text: Like this house little Danny and I made at day camp.  Oh, thank goodness, it made it through unscathed.  Just a little water damage in the basement.  Just like this house...

speaker: Frasier
text: Phillip, you are still their father.  I mean, I know things seem difficult right now, but believe me, it'll get easier.

speaker: Phillip
text: Oh, it's already easier.  I mean, look at me, I'm dressed.

speaker: Lana
text: Phillip, you know what would really cheer you up, is to make a killing on this house!  Now, don't you think you should get back to work?

speaker: Phillip
text: I guess.  That air traffic isn't gonna control itself. [_gets up_]

speaker: Lana
text: OK, here we go. [_he heads toward the front_] No, not the front door!  Let's go out the side door. [_steers him_] It's good to see you again, Phillip, I'll call you when we sell the place, bye!

speaker: Frasier
text: Good lord, that man is obviously in pain, the least you could be is a little sympathetic!

speaker: Lana
text: I have _been_ sympathetic for _fifteen months_!  I had him over for Thanksgiving!  He got drunk the first half-hour and cried himself to sleep in my coat closet!  And I consider that one of our good days!

speaker: Frasier
text: Well, so where are these so-called buyers of yours?  You told me they'd be here in a few minutes.

speaker: Lana
text: Well, they're obviously running late, OK?  It'll give us time to go over the plan.

speaker: Frasier
text: What, what, there's a plan?

speaker: Lana
text: Well, sure.  When the Smolenskis get here, you act like you want the house.  You know, a little competition, put a little pressure on the deal.

speaker: Frasier
text: You're asking me to be your shill?

speaker: Lana
text: [_slaps her forehead in mock surprise_] That's the word!  Yes, yes!  Now listen, you don't have to say anything!

speaker: Frasier
text: I'm sorry, no!

speaker: Lana
text: Well, why not?!  Well, look, OK, all you have to do is walk around with an interested look on your face.  You know, they'll fill in the rest!

speaker: Frasier
text: I will do no such thing!

speaker: Lana
text: Why won't you help me?!

speaker: Frasier
text: Because I refuse to lie for you!

speaker: Lana
text: Oh fine, then go wait in the car!

speaker: Frasier
text: I never wanted to leave the car!

speaker: Lana
text: Oh, just get out! _She grabs his coat and flings it at him, hitting the stick house and shattering it into a hundred pieces.  They are both horrified.  END OF ACT ONE  ACT TWO  Scene Four - House Lana is picking up the pieces.  Frasier comes in the door with a grocery bag._

speaker: Frasier
text: All right, I got some cream-sicles, and fudge-sicles, and something they call, uh, "Bomb Pops!"

speaker: Lana
text: I called the Smolenskis, I bought us a little extra time.

speaker: Frasier
text: Right, good, good.  All right, let's spread out some paper and then build us a house!

speaker: Lana
text: So Frasier, with all your talk about honesty, how do you justify faking this thing?

speaker: Frasier
text: Well... we're simply protecting the feelings of an innocent man.  Nothing dishonest about that.

speaker: Lana
text: Uh-huh. [_holds up a piece_] So, uh, are you gonna write, "I love you, Daddy" or am I?

speaker: Frasier
text: [_It's a dirty job, but_] I'll do it. _FADE TO:  Scene Five - Park Daphne watches, delighted, as Tank obeys Jim's every command._

speaker: Jim
text: Sit.  Wave, wave.  All right, hide your eyes, hide your eyes. Hide 'em... _Niles and Eddie are sitting on the bench watching them. In his loneliness, Niles has begun to pet Eddie._

speaker: Niles
text: Hey Eddie, don't worry about that other dog.  He may be bigger and flashier and better-looking, but...you have substance. She knows that.

speaker: Daphne
text: [_coming back_] How amazing is Jim?  He's so connected to animals, it's almost magical.

speaker: Niles
text: Daphne, I've been musing about you and me, and I have a thought.

speaker: Daphne
text: Yeah?

speaker: Niles
text: In every healthy relationship, I may ask for an occasional - very occasional - irrational demand.

speaker: Daphne
text: What do you mean?

speaker: Niles
text: Uh, a thing we insist the other do or not do, and the other one has to do it or not do it, without question.

speaker: Daphne
text: Is that fair?

speaker: Niles
text: It is.  Because we each get one, and only one, for our whole relationship.

speaker: Daphne
text: Well, if it's important to you.

speaker: Niles
text: Then it's agreed?

speaker: Daphne
text: Agreed.

speaker: Niles
text: Good... oh, I've got mine!

speaker: Daphne
text: Already?

speaker: Niles
text: Yes.  Uh, I want you to promise never to come to this dog park again.

speaker: Daphne
text: What?

speaker: Niles
text: I know it sounds extreme, even unreasonable - but that's the beauty of the irrational demand.

speaker: Daphne
text: Is this about Jim?

speaker: Niles
text: The, uh, demand cannot be scrutinized.  It is, by definition, irrational.

speaker: Daphne
text: And are you sure this is how you want to use your only one?

speaker: Niles
text: Absolutely.  I've thought this through, a lot.  Irrationally, of course.

speaker: Daphne
text: OK, if you're sure.  I promise never to come to this dog park again.

speaker: Niles
text: Thank you.  I knew you'd understand. [_kisses her_]  Jim and Tank come over. _

speaker: Jim
text: All right, we're going home.  Tank needs to re-hydrate, and, oof, I'm late for a deltoid workout.

speaker: Daphne
text: Well, I guess this is goodbye, Jim.

speaker: Jim
text: Yep, by this time next week I'll be leading my first raft tour in Chile.

speaker: Niles
text: Really?

speaker: Jim
text: Yeah.

speaker: Niles
text: Wow, when do you get back?

speaker: Daphne
text: Oh, he's not coming back.  He's moving there. [_to Jim_] Good luck, Jim.

speaker: Jim
text: Yes, you too. [_hugs her; to Niles_] And, uh, stay cool, buddy.

speaker: Niles
text: Oh, you know it.

speaker: Daphne
text: [_sighs_] I wonder how I'll use my irrational demand... oh, what's my rush?  I've got years to think it over. _Niles looks very nervous.  FADE TO:  Scene Six - Waiting Room Martin is still seated in the waiting room.  Joanne, a woman in her early 50's, comes in and sees him.  They seem comfortable with each other, but nervous about something else._

speaker: Joanne
text: Hi, Martin.

speaker: Martin
text: Hello, Joanne.

speaker: Joanne
text: How have you been?

speaker: Martin
text: Pretty good.  Oh please, have a seat.

speaker: Joanne
text: Thanks. [_sits_] I was worried I was going to be late with all that construction going on.

speaker: Martin
text: Yeah, I know, it's a mess.

speaker: Joanne
text: How's your hip?

speaker: Martin
text: Ah, you learn to live with it.

speaker: Joanne
text: I think about you a lot, you know.  I've wanted to call, but... I don't know.

speaker: Martin
text: I understand, it's OK.

speaker: Joanne
text: So... another year has gone by.

speaker: Martin
text: Yeah.  Time really flies.

speaker: Joanne
text: I guess it goes a little slower for me. _Silence.  FADE TO:  Scene Seven - House Frasier and Lana are eating popsicles and finishing their new house, which is now only lacking a roof._

speaker: Frasier
text: How's our roof coming?

speaker: Lana
text: Almost done.

speaker: Frasier
text: Good. [_looks at her_] You know, there was a time back in high school when I would have paid a thousand dollars to watch you eat a popsicle. _She just looks at him with the popsicle in her mouth... and bites off the end, making him flinch._

speaker: Frasier
text: It was a long time ago.

speaker: Lana
text: I think it's kind of funny that we became friends.

speaker: Frasier
text: We're friends?

speaker: Lana
text: Well, sure we are.  Why wouldn't you think so?

speaker: Frasier
text: Oh, dear...

speaker: Lana
text: Nice going, dipstick! [_takes a tissue and wipes his shirt_]

speaker: Frasier
text: It's a brand-new shirt.

speaker: Lana
text: I hear a car.  It's the Smolenskis. [_gets up_] OK, keep working.

speaker: Frasier
text: Right.

speaker: Lana
text: I gotta go up to Phil's room and spray some air freshener around.  His room reeks of... I don't know, despair! _She leaves the room.  Frasier, before resuming work, takes the scissors and cuts a hole in the middle of a large piece of wall-paper on the floor, and puts it over his head as a smock, all the while holding the popsicle in his mouth.  As he resumes, the elderly Smolenskis come in._

speaker: Mrs. Smolenski
text: It's even nicer than I remember! _They see him - a grown man wearing a huge paper smock, glueing sticks together and sucking on a popsicle._

speaker: Mrs. Smolenski
text: Well, hello there!  Are you having fun making your little house?

speaker: Lana
text: Oh, there you are!  Hi - oh, I see you've met Frasier. I am so glad you came today, because the interest on this place is really heating up!

speaker: Mr. Smolenski
text: Well, we're certainly interested as well, but we've- we've heard that a lot of homes in this area have a flooding problem.  Now, what do you know about the basement here?

speaker: Lana
text: Honestly?

speaker: Mr. Smolenski
text: Yes.

speaker: Lana
text: This house is sixty years old, and I have only heard of it flooding once.

speaker: Mr. Smolenski
text: Oh!

speaker: Lana
text: And I could tell you for a fact that the permanent owner stores some of his most cherished keepsakes in that basement.

speaker: Mrs. Smolenski
text: Are you choking on your lolly?

speaker: Frasier
text: [_takes out popsicle_] No.  I am choking on something far more dangerous and destructive than a simple sugary treat.  It's a prolific and powerful poison known as: deception!

speaker: Mrs. Smolenski
text: He's very verbal! _Even from within his smock, Frasier manages to look righteous and accusing._

speaker: Lana
text: Oh, you know, I just remembered!  Gosh, you know, the owner did mention something about a recent little moisture problem downstairs.  Tell you what, why don't I give him a call and see if he'll come down just a tiny bit in the price?

speaker: Mrs. Smolenski
text: Oh, that'd be wonderful!

speaker: Mr. Smolenski
text: If he could give us a break in the price, I'm sure we'll make an offer.

speaker: Lana
text: Oh, great!  I'll call you tonight.

speaker: Mrs. Smolenski
text: Thank you.

speaker: Mr. Smolenski
text: [_to Frasier_] Bye, sonny.

speaker: Lana
text: [_as they leave_] Call you tonight!

speaker: Frasier
text: There now, you see?  You did the right thing.  That wasn't so bad, was it?

speaker: Lana
text: I guess not.  Oh, look at our little house, it looks great!

speaker: Frasier
text: Say, you know, we got a few extra popsicle sticks left, why don't we add on a half a bath? _Lana laughs.  Frasier heads for the side door, then stops and turns back._

speaker: Frasier
text: You know, Lana, I think the house should go the other way around - with the door facing the couch. [_off her look_] Feng Shui!

speaker: Lana
text: Fine, fine, fine, fine. _He leaves the room.  Lana lifts the house - and the coffee table comes with it.  She tries again, without luck.  She braces the table with her legs, and tugs.  Nothing.  Making a rapid decision, she lifts the coffee table and turns it around so the door is now facing the couch.  Frasier comes back._

speaker: Frasier
text: Ah, perfect.

speaker: Lana
text: Perfect.

speaker: Frasier
text: Now you see, doesn't it feel good to tell the truth? It's like breathing a breath of fresh air, and-

speaker: Lana
text: Yeah, yeah, yeah, let's go!

speaker: Frasier
text: Oh, all right. _They go out the door.  FADE TO:_ **MOMMIE DEAREST** _Scene Eight - Apartment Roz steps off the elevator carrying Alice.  She kneels down and stands Alice opposite her._

speaker: Roz
text: OK, Alice, before we see Uncle Frasier, let's remember together what _really_ happened.

speaker: Roz
text: Now, did you throw up in Uncle Frasier's car?

speaker: Roz
text: No-you-didn't.  That smell was there before, wasn't it?

speaker: Roz
text: That's-my-girl. [_holds out a pack of M &M;'s_] There you go. _FADE TO:  Scene Nine - Hearing Room David Hicks, a man in his 20's, is sitting in a chair, wearing a denim prison uniform.  In front of him are the three members of a Parole Board.  Behind him, the room is empty except for Martin, Joanne, and a guard._

speaker: David
text: And besides the library assignment, I've been taking a computer class on Wednesdays.  I hope to get a job with computers... when I get out.

speaker: 1st BM
text: Can you tell us what consideration, if any, you've given this crime?

speaker: David
text: Well... I regret it, everyday.  I was young at the time, and I wasn't thinking - you know, about the consequences.  And I'm very sorry.

speaker: 2nd BM
text: The victim is here.  Mr. Crane? [_Martin stands up_] Would you like to make a statement?

speaker: Martin
text: I have nothing to say. [_sits back down_]

speaker: 3rd BM
text: Would you give us a moment?

speaker: 3rd BM
text: Mr. Hicks, the board commends you for your participation in the in-house programs to better yourself, and for your record of excellent conduct.  We have weighed this against your conviction of shooting a police officer during the commission of a robbery -- and find that the length of your time served has not yet met the standards for proportionality, equality, and justice as required by state law.  Parole is denied. _As the Parole Board gets up and leaves the room, the guard comes forward to take David back to his cell.  Joanne begins to cry, softly. Martin rises, considering whether or not to say anything to her - and then decides to leave quietly.  END OF ACT TWO_
